repnme.cdata!: Guinea - Health and Nutrition Sector Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. Lessons underline what
            can be achieved through commitment and focus, in a low
            resource environment, and with limitations in highly skilled
            personnel. The Government commitment was evident in the
            policy actions, and changes in management in the Ministry of
            Public Health and Social Affairs, and in the delivery
            objectives that improved health. However, while
            sustainability is likely, renewed donor commitment will be
            required for the long-term; and, household surveys need to
            be conducted to ensure continued access to services. Most
            importantly, Guinea has shown the potential to manage
            complex health programs, which with the strong project unit
            support, and strengthened regional administration proved
            satisfactory. Nonetheless, issues in project design
            presented initial difficulties, particularly in iodine
            interventions, an issue that requires more critical
            technical oversight at appraisal. The successful financial
            management and local contracting, is an experience that
            should be built on, to determine the potential local ability
            to undertake larger projects. However this is a challenge
            that translates sustaining the health facility structures,
            into actual services, and improved health care delivery,
            requiring further Government, and stakeholder commitments,
            as well as escalating the utilization level of health
            services to the rural poor, and linking traditional healers
            with the formal system. It is important that Government
            consider policies for private sector participation in the
            health sector, and, for exploiting opportunities for
            inter-sectoral collaboration, by addressing health issues,
            where community poverty alleviation programs could be
            designed, and mainstreamed into the different infrastructure
            sector projects.

repnme.cdata!: Guinea - Health and Nutrition Sector Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the project is
            to expand coverage of low cost health services in order to
            improve the health status of the communities reached. The
            project will support measures and activities to: (a) expand
            coverage and improve quality of the health, nutrition and
            family planning delivery system; and (b) improve sector
            organization, management and resource mobilization. As part
            of the Government's health program (1992-2000), the
            project will focus on: (a) improving service coverage and
            quality through: (i) a phased rehabilitation and maintenance
            program for health facilities involving community
            participation; (ii) supply essential drugs, vaccines and
            iodized capsules to health facilities; and (iii)
            strengthening key technical programs to improve diagnostic
            and treatment capabilities, staff performance, and
            information and education to communities; and (b)
            strengthening sector organization and management through:
            (i) adoption of a revised Ministry of Public Health and
            Social Affairs (MSPAS) structure, light rehabilitation of
            the central services building, maintenance of facilities and
            operation of administrative health facilities and teams;
            (ii) improved systems for financial, material and human
            resource management; and (iii) generation of new resources
            through user fees and support for adequate budgetary allocations.
